utterances: I think people are clearly worried about Iraq.
People really have a great fear today that terrorists will do exactly what they said they're going to do - and that is to take down the United States of America if we don't act.
And that leads us to a world that we all recognize is insecure because the terrorists have successfully, in the past, addressed this.
The economy is breaking through.
And people can say well, it's not breaking through.
We need to do better messaging.
We need to look the voter in the eye and say if Nancy Pelosi takes over the House of Representatives and Charlie Rangel gets his ways, the Bush tax cuts are taken off the table.

If we get that sort of message out there over the next three and a half, the next four days, I am confident that we will keep control of the United States Senate, and I believe we have a good shot at keeping control of the House of Representatives.
And what do you say to voters who say what are you going to do about Iraq?
How are you going to change what's going on there?

We need to call upon the Muslim - the moderate Muslim nations, like Jordan and like Saudi Arabia, and I would include Egypt in there - to take an increasing position, increasing prominence in affecting what goes on by the religious entities in Iraq.
Iraq has to stand up, their government has to stand up over the next month, two months, three months, in the near future, and disarm the militias.
They have to pass economic reform to allow distribution of the oil royalties so that we can get down and clean up the streets and guarantee security there throughout Iraq.
Senate Majority Leader Bill Frist of Tennessee.
Thank you for joining us.
In fact, since 2013, the U.S.
has missed out on over $2 billion worth of leaked natural gas.
But the Trump administration argues that captured natural gas would not pay off.
That compliance and implementation is too expensive.
In any case, Wold prefers answering to Wyoming.
We always believe that the closer regulation to the individual, whether it's from the county or from the state, it's better than having it regulated by the government.
Federal.
Washington D.C.
Pennsylvania and Virginia are also working on their own methane regulations.
Meanwhile, it's not clear if the federal rollbacks will actually happen.
They face legal challenges.
For NPR News, I'm Cooper McKim.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
Im Rebecca Roberts in Washington.
Neal Conan is away.
We're going to spend most of this hour talking about Kent State, where 40 years ago tomorrow, the Ohio National Guard killed four student protestors.
What do you remember?
What did that event mean to you?
You can email us now, talk@npr.org.
But first we go to New York City, where over the weekend, someone drove an SUV packed with firecrackers, fertilizer, gasoline and tanks of propane into Times Square.
A street vendor noticed smoke coming out of the vehicle and flagged down a mounted policeman and minutes later, police had cleared the busy intersection at West 45th Street.
The SUV never detonated, but law enforcement officials say if it had, it would have caused injuries, casualties and chaos.
If you have a question about what happened, our number is 800-989-8255.
Our email address is talk@npr.org.
Joining us now is Arun Venugopal.
He is a reporter at member station WNYC in New York City, and he joins us from there.
It's good to have you with us.
Hi, thanks Rebecca.
So you were in Times Square this morning.
Any signs of what went on over the weekend?
You know, it really seems like it's already become history fast.
You would not know that anything happened on Saturday.
It just, it's really returned to normal.
Tourists are back there.
It's kind of wet, so it's been a slow day tourism-wise, but still, people are out there taking pictures.
When you ask them about the event on Saturday, some of them seem to be so blasï¿½ about it already.
And there's not a heightened police presence or anything?
It's subtle.

Yes, there are I spoke to an officer there in Times Square and he said that right now, there are two officers per block instead of the regular one, but it's not the kind of thing that you would - really sticks out.
And if you didn't know that, you would not think that it's anything unusual about it.
So this happened on Saturday evening.
Can you give us the sort of basics of what we know and where it went from there?
That's right.
As far as the authorities are concerned, they think that it was - the vehicle was left at this location, right there in the heart of Times Square on 45th Street, at 6:28.
This is probably just when people are starting to head into dinner in case they're going to take in a Broadway show.
So there would be a lot of people there.
It was a warm day, a lot of tourists in town.
It's really, if you're looking to cause trouble, it's a good time to do it, I guess you could say.
But very soon after it was left, it was abandoned, within a couple minutes, a couple people, vendors there's a lot of these street vendors in the area.
Many of them are actually Vietnam veterans.
They get priority when it comes to being able to sell things in different parts of the city.
They noticed that this car had been left there at a spot that it shouldn't have been and that it was actually running.
And so, one of them went over - I met with one of them, and he his name is Duane Jackson(ph), and he just thought it was strange that this car was running.
He looked inside, and he saw the keys were still in there, thought it was odd.
And just right around then, the officer, the mounted officer, he happened to come around.
I think he had been alerted by the other vendor by the name of Lance Horton.
And he came by, they started checking it out, and pretty soon, smoke started coming out of the back.
And that's when he and a few other officers started clearing the area.
I think even one of the vendors who I spoke to, he said even then, he didn't quite think it was anything unusual so much as just something was going wrong with the car.
But then soon enough, they had the bomb squad out there.
They had the robots who were, I guess, probing into this vehicle, shattering the windows and investigating, and they find the contents in the back of this vehicle.

It's a Nissan Pathfinder, and it's got this whole array of wires, clocks, three tanks of propane, a couple of tanks of gasoline and then a gun locker, which they would later discover contained eight bags of fertilizer.
As it turns out, the fertilizer was not explosive.

It kind of makes you scratch your head and wonder exactly what this person was like in terms of how much they knew what they were doing or not, but nonetheless, with all the other contents of the car, the police say it could've been a pretty dangerous situation.
It could've killed people.
The explosion couldve ripped open the car.
It probably would've been short, they say, of say, destroying a building, nothing on the order of, say, Oklahoma City, though.
And what are the leads in terms of who parked that car, who the car belongs to and who's claiming responsibility?
Well, various people are claiming responsibility.
A couple groups are kind of latching on.

You know, if you want to kind of claim responsibility, nothing like doing something in New York City or associating yourself with, you know, with a cause here because it gets so much coverage, of course, and that kind of percolates through the rest of the world very fast.
But the police are not really kind of showing their hand at this moment on that.
They have tracked down the owner of the car, who they do not believe, so far, theyve not described him as a suspect.
They think that it was perhaps the license plate actually, license plates that were on this car were stolen from a repair shop in Connecticut.
They've, you know, they've been going through various leads.
I'm Rebecca Roberts.
It's TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.

They've seen a photo, some video footage, I think, from a tourist who was in the area who caught a stranger, a white man in his 40s, who happened to nearby, just down the block, around the corner from the car, and they saw him, they recorded him taking off his shirt.
It was a dark shirt.
He was taking it off this is outside and revealing another shirt underneath, and they don't refer to him as a suspect, however.
They called him a person of interest because they don't have any reason to believe yet that he was definitely somebody who parked that car, but they just they refer to it as furtive movements.
So they're kind of, I guess, describing it somewhat subjectively.
They think that he's definitely somebody they want to talk to, and they're trying to make it sound a little nicer and a little more welcoming.
They mayor's been trying to bring him on in.
But so far, no word on whether they've actually met this person or not.

And Arun, what's your sense as a New Yorker of whether, you know, what the street vendors noticed and their quick reaction and the amount of policemen paying attention and even the tourist training his video camera?
Is this sort of the heightened citizen vigilance in a post-9/11 New York, or is this just the usual hustle bustle of Times Square?
Well, I think, you know, the thing with post-9/11 is it's very easy for a lot of people it has been, what, eight and a half, almost nine years now.

And so I - my sense is it's not really sort of a permanent state of awareness so much as, yes, you do have a lot of people who happen to be recording things in the area, and when police put the call out, then immediately people started submitting their videotape.
And I'm sure other people are submitting, you know, information they have.
So that's, I guess, part of the new media reality we live in now.
As far as the vendors are concerned, these might be the best-informed people in that area because they are always there.
They really know every block and sort of the rhythms of the street.
A lot of them are military veterans, as I said.
So they have a certain awareness.
At least one gentleman spoke to, he really thinks that that's part of their, I guess the asset that they bring to the street.
They're sort of the extended security apparatus of New York City, even if the police don't actually necessarily, you know, look at them in that way.

But you know, this is really the basic, raw street intelligence that makes a difference, I think, in a lot of these situations, it looks like, in recent history, where it really comes down to some person on the street who sees something a little unusual.
Even the police officers, they're kind of rotated in and out of the area as policy.
And so, it's really these vendors, I think, who are, you know, I guess perhaps the best assets in the area.
Let's take a quick call from Brian(ph) in Boise, Idaho.
Brian, welcome to TALK OF THE NATION.
Hi.
Hi, you're on the air.
Hi, you know, I just kind of had a question, wanted to get a comment from your guest.

The first thing I thought when I saw this story and saw the type of bomb that was inside of this vehicle, you know, a couple of propane tanks, some containers filled with gasoline and a couple of clocks and then that combined with the fact that it didn't go off or, you know, apparently either failed or wasn't concealed very well, it seemed like it was, you know, not a full-blown terrorist attempt.
It seemed kind of juvenile and thrown together compared with the, you know, extremely organized terrorist attacks we see internationally and obviously 9/11.
So I didn't know if your guest had a comment on that as far as, you know, how you qualify it against, you know, real, full-blown terrorist threats.
Brian, thanks for your call.

Yeah, well, I mean, I'm not in a position to really say to what extent I mean, I definitely think the word that's been thrown around by Mayor Bloomberg here in New York, as well as others, is amateurish.
Of course, that should be, I suppose, taken with a grain of salt considering that they are also describing that it couldve been very dangerous.
And that I think Police Commissioner Ray Kelly here of the NYPD said that, you know, it was a workable bomb.
So it is very odd.
I think there have been some experts who think that it definitely displays a level of sort of a guy working on his own or on a very small level.
But I think that federal officials are still really kind of, you know, keeping their options open at this point.
So, probably still a lot left that, you know, needs to be learned.
So theyve tracked down the owner of the car, but they're not calling him a suspect.
They've got this interesting guy on camera, but they're not calling him a suspect.
What are the police telling you about where this goes?
